Liverpool have released their £50million plans for a new training base at Kirkby, with the consultation process taking place on Wednesday. 
Residents and businesses in Kirkby will get the opportunity to view the proposals — which incorporate the academy and the first team — in detail and discuss the redevelopment of the Reds’ Academy site with members of the project team. 
Representatives from LFC, Knowsley council as well as planning and construction experts, will be available for questioning at Northwood Community Centre in Kirkby from 2pm until 8pm, report the Liverpool Echo. 
The LFC project includes the building of a new combined training centre, the redevelopment of the existing facilities and a new viewing stand for 499 spectators. The current main pitch at Kirkby would have a roof added and be converted into a covered full-size indoor artificial pitch. 
The new training centre would include a pool and hydrotherapy complex, gymnasium and specialist sports rehabilitation suites. 
Combining the first team and Academy on to one-site has been a long held ambition for the Reds with Jurgen Klopp particularly keen to see the move progress. First image released of Liverpool's planned new £50m Kirkby training complex (Photo: KSS) 
The enclosed geography of the current first team base at Melwood in West Derby make it impossible to expand there so plans have been drawn up by architects KSS - the firm behind the new Main Stand at Anfield - for expansion at Kirkby. 
That requires LFC to buy some 14 acres of the current community playing fields at Simonswood Lane adjacent to the Academy - bringing the total site up to 60 acres - with the Reds in return providing five new and improved football pitches and sports facilities in the area. Part of Moss Lane between Simonswood Lane and Arbour Lane would have to be closed. 
The club says it will work closely with local football teams, including Kirkby AFC, on the upgrade of the community pitches so they can host top-level amateur matches with new drainage, changing facilities and car park. Steel containers are currently used as changing rooms while the pitches can often be unplayable due to surface water. Gates to the rear of Liverpool's Academy in Kirkby (Photo: Liverpool Echo) 
The surrounding area will also see improvements which include new dog-walking and cycling paths, new lighting and improved security with a CCTV system. 
Liverpool hope work on the project could start early next year and be completed by the summer of 2019 with the Reds' first-team squad making the switch to Kirkby for pre-season training ahead of the 2019/20 season. Read More 
The club will be anxious to win hearts and minds among the Kirkby community so objections can be kept to a minimum and the relatively ambitious timetable can remain on track. 
For more information and the opportunity to comment, residents are asked to visit: www.simonswoodlaneconsultation.co.uk Like us on Facebook
